narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to digest high level neuroscience research papers and explain them clearly and succinctly. I also got a lot of value from the final project which was very open ended so we could work on things that interested us.
Developed knowledge on the literature related to the neural substrates of decision-making.
I learned a lot about areas of research in human neuroscience and decision making. I got more comfortable reading these types of academic papers and discussing them.
Brain areas and processes associated with various core components of decision-making in everyday life.
I learned how to understand and critically evaluate neuroscience papers.
This course covers the neuroscience of decision-making in various contexts, with special attention to current applications.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Crockett was very kind and understanding of our circumstances. She also made class fun and enjoyable and included a much-needed break in the middle. The workload was not overwhelming. She also scheduled meetings throughout the semester to chat with her about our final project which kept us on track. I think the class could be improved by having some content each week prepared by the professor instead of only relying on student led presentations. Professor Crockett is a really great teacher so I wish we had a little more of that.

Teacher and material was absolutely incredible. If lectures were recorded or class notes were provided, it would have been easier to synthesize material. Maybe a little more structure could be beneficial - otherwise discussions can be forgotten quite quickly.

Dr. Crockett is a wonderful professor - very sweet and engaging. I liked that the format of the class was very consistent and that she always began class with a check-in. Overall it wasn't a very stressful course at all.
The seminar structure worked really well for engagement! I liked the kickstarts and guided-discussion. Dr. Crockett did a great job of nudging discussion along but not dominating it.
Amazing course.
I enjoyed the open discussion format. I feel that the jumpstarts could use more guidance.
This course is incredibly well-structured. The themes build on the prior weeks, with the topics getting more and more complex without being overwhelming.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Really appreciate the break in the middle and general considerateness and understanding. Professor Crockett gave us a survey to fill out at the start where we could explain personal circumstances and concerns.

We split into breakout rooms to discuss one of the assigned readings, then we came back and someone presented the info. Some people would share their screen and do a presentation on all of the papers. I think this system worked fairly well and we used it throughout the semester. It was up to the presenters to think of something engaging to do for their presentation - demo, game, Poll Everywhere, etc.
Including breaks and polls was helpful.

The use of breakout rooms was helpful to foster relationships between students who, for the most part, have never met in person. Breakout rooms also created opportunities to hear from more students, who were less inclined to share with the whole group, and I enjoyed hearing their thoughts.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! I enjoyed the class.
Absolutely if you are interested in neuroscience/decision-making

Yes, I would recommend this class to someone who's somewhat familiar with neuroscience/reading science papers and interested in behavior. I will admit, however, there is not as much discussion on economic/business concepts -- at least not really until the last week or so -- in case that's what you're hoping for out of the class. Nonetheless, would definitely recommend because Dr. Crockett is great and the class is not at all stressful (read the papers and write a response each week and that's really it until the final paper). She even gave us a ~15 minute break every class.
Yes! If you have taken some neuro/psych background, this class will be a great expansion upon it. Really interesting content and amazing professor.
Yes!
Very highly!
Absolutely! The course provides a lot of technical information in an accessible manner. Professor Crockett is phenomenal, and I highly recommend taking a class with her if you can.
